description: Gifted by France to the United States in 1886, the Statue of Liberty stands at 305 feet from the ground to the tip of the torch and is an iconic symbol of freedom and democracy. This colossal neoclassical sculpture on Liberty Island in New York Harbor welcomes visitors from around the globe.
name: Statue of Liberty
Three WTC
description: Part of the new World Trade Center complex, Three World Trade Center features a height of 1,079 feet and offers a striking glass fa√ßade. Completed in 2018, it contributes to the revitalization of Lower Manhattan and stands as a testament to modern architectural design.

Also known as the Freedom Tower. As the main building of the rebuilt World Trade Center complex, One World Trade Center soars to a patriotic height of 1,776 feet - the year of the declaration of independence - making it the tallest building in the Western Hemisphere. Completed in 2014, it's a symbol of resilience and renewal after the events of September 11, 2001.
name: One WTC

description: With its distinctive gilded spire, the New York Life Building is a classic example of the Gothic Revival skyscraper and stretches up to 615 feet. Completed in 1928, it remains a key feature of the Madison Square Park skyline.
name: NY Life Building

description: Designed by Frank Lloyd Wright and completed in 1959, the Guggenheim Museum is not only a repository of modern art but also an architectural landmark. Its unique spiral design and inverted-ziggurat exterior stand out in Manhattan's Upper East Side.
name: Guggenheim Museum

description: An enduring symbol of New York City, the Empire State Building reaches 1,454 feet with its antenna and held the title of the world's tallest building for nearly 40 years after its completion in 1931, and again after 9/11. This Art Deco masterpiece is a staple of the city's tourist attractions and offers sweeping panoramic views from its observatories.
name: Empire State Building

description: Also knows as 4 Times Square, the tower is known as a pioneer in green building practices, the Conde Nast Building stands at 809 feet and was completed in 1999. Its prominent location at Times Square and the use of an LED display for Nasdaq gives it a unique presence in the city.
name: Conde Nast Building

description: An iconic example of Art Deco architecture, the Chrysler Building was the tallest in the world upon its completion in 1930, reaching 1,046 feet. Its gleaming stainless steel crown and spire remain a distinctive element in the cityscape.
name: Chrysler Building

description: Built in 1892 to celebrate the centennial of George Washington's inauguration, the Washington Square Arch is a marble Roman triumphal arch that stands 77 feet tall. It is a historic landmark and a focal point of Washington Square Park, a hub for artists, students, and activists.
name: Washington Square Arch

description: This skyscraper boasts a pinnacle height of 1,200 feet, making it one of the most prominent on the NYC skyline and is renowned for its environmentally sustainable design. Completed in 2009, it's not only a visual marvel but also one of the most ecologically friendly buildings, earning a platinum LEED certification.
name: Bank of America Tower
